value.title: Coronavirus: India's pandemic lockdown turns into a human tragedy

value.title: SE Asia Stocks-Drop on coronavirus jitters; Singapore eases monetary policy sharply
value.excerpt: Singapore c.bank eases monetary policy aggressively * Malaysia warns of surge in coronavirus cases in mid-April * Indonesia faces calls to tighten movement restrictions By Arundhati Dutta March 30 (Reuters) - Southeast Asian stock markets dropped on Monday as worries over a severe economic damage in the region following a rise in new coronavirus cases outweighed central banks' efforts to calm investor nerves through aggressive policy easing.

value.title: japan expands entry ban to u.s., china, south korea and most of europe – Asahi
value.excerpt: The EUR/USD pair closed the week with substantial gains around 1.1140, as the market sold-off the greenback ahead of London’s fix. EUR/USD surged to a weekly high on Friday amid dollar´s sell-off, retains its short-term bullish stance. The Sterling was among the most benefited from USD weakness at the end of the week, with GBP/USD reaching a two-week high of 1.2485, to close the day at around 1.2450. Dollar’s sell-off triggered a rally, no real reasons for Pound’s strength. Despite the coronavirus (COVID-19) fears, USD/JPY refrains from extending the previous two days’ declines while rising to 107.95 amid the early Monday morning in Asia. Risk-tone remains under pressure, measures to combat the pandemic in focus. Gold has closed the last full week of a turbulent March around $1,626.The Technical Confluences Indicator is showing that significant support awaits at $1,625, which is the convergence of the SMA 10-4h, the SMA 100-15m. Thanks to swift action worldwide by central banks, global equities avoided a disastrous place, a possible combination of a 1930’s like depression and the 2008 financial crisis. In just a matter of weeks, massive monetary and fiscal stimulus was injected into the global economy. Note: All information on this page is subject to change. value.title: 'No farewells, no ceremonies': China's Hubei cremates coronavirus dead
value.excerpt: Ten unclaimed urns sit in the crematorium city in central China’s Hubei province hard-hit by coronavirus. Not only are funerals banned across China, in places like Jingzhou bereaved relatives who are stuck in their homes must wait even to retrieve the remains of their loved ones.

images.title: 'No farewells, no ceremonies': China's Hubei cremates coronavirus dead
